name: Glossae Shorter Than Paraglossae
description: Glossae much shorter than the paraglossae.

name: Thoracic Gills
description: Multi-branched, thread-like gills present laterally and ventrally on thorax, but not on abdomen.

name: Divergent Wing Pads
description: Wingpads are not parallel with body, angled away from the midline of the body.

name: Gills Unlike Peltoperlidae
description: Unlike Peltoperlidae, gills, if present, are not conical, and thoracic sterna do not overlap.

name: Hind Legs Don't Reach
description: When extended, hind legs do not reach end of the abdomen.

name: Paraglossae And Glossae Subequal
description: Paraglossae and glossae about same length, suitable for shredding.

name: Tarsal Segments Subequal
description: The first and second segment of the tarsus on all legs are the same length. The tarsus is the, most distal leg region (last part of a leg before the claw), often divided into subsegments. When counting tarsal segments, start with the semgent closest to the body.

name: All Nota Sclerotized
description: Pro-, meso-, and metanota entirely covered by sclerites (i.e. the dorsal side of all 3 thoracic segments is hardened).

name: Retreat
description: Larvae build stationary retreats of silk, detritus and rock fragments, often used for filter feeding. These usually fall apart when removed from the water, but you may see some rements when flping over rocks to search for larvae, it will look like a clup of loose slime (silk) and small rock pieces.

name: Setal Fan On Prolegs
description: Base of each anal proleg (fleshy nubs at end of body) with conspicuous tuft or fan of long hairs .

name: Ventral Branched Abdominal Gills
description: Abdomen with rows of branched gills ventrally.

name: Forelegs With Long Hair
description: Femora (thighs) and tibia (shins) of forelegs have long setae along the inner margins.

name: Minnow-like
description: Larvae with streamlined, minnow-like body shape.

name: Antenna Between Mandibles and Eyes
description: As in all families of superfamily Limnephiloidea, the short, inconspicuous antennae are each located about midway between the base of the mandible and the eye.

name: Lateral Filaments
description: Abdominal segments 1–8 with paired, 2-segemented, lateral filaments (slender conical appendages on sides of abdomen)

name: Prolegs With Two Claws
description: End of abdomen has a pair of anal prolegs (fleshy nubs at the end of the abdomen), each bearing a 2 claws.

name: Lateral Filaments on 1-7
description: Abdominal segments 1–7 each with pair of lateral filaments each divided into 4–5 segments.

name: Long Tail
description: End of abdomen with single long filament.

name: Head Partially Hidden
description: Head usually partially contracted into thorax.

name: Transverse Coxae
description: Forelegs (1st pair of legs) have the coxae (leg segment nearest the body) transverse (not round as in Elmidae).

name: Unique Antenna
description: Each antenna 11-segmented, usually with enlarged basal segment and expanded 2nd segment covering remaining antennal segments.

name: Visible Trochantins
description: Trochantins visible, unlike Elmidae. This is a small sclerite near where the leg connects with the body.

name: Coxal Plate Not Wedge-like
description: Broad wedge-like hind coxal plate absent.

name: Extended Hind Coxae
description: Hind coxae (basal most leg segment) each with median portion extending in posterior direction, dividing abdominal segment 1 into lateral sclerites, but not expanding into broad plates (see Halipidae for example of broad plates).

name: Large Spurs Absent
description: Without large spur on end of each front tibia (shin).

name: Scutellum Usually Visible
description: Scutellum (triangular sclerite between the elytra) usually visible, if hidden, then front and middle tarsi apparently 4-segmented and hind tarsi each with 1 claw.

name: 5-Segmented Tarsi
description: Each leg with 5 tarsal segments.

name: Big Claws
description: Big Claws

name: Last Tarsal Segment Subequal
description: Last tarsal segment about as long as other segments

name: Thread-like Antennae
description: Antennae slender, thread-like

name: 4 Eyes
description: Compound eyes divided into separate dorsal and ventral portions ( "4-eyed" appearance).

name: Expanded Hind Coxae
description: Each hind coxa (first segment of the last leg) expanded into a broad, flat, plate, ventrally covering the first 2 or 3 abdominal segments and most of hind femora.

name: 5 Segments Before Cupule
description: Antenna ually with 5 segments before cupule (cup-shaped, hairless, segment 6)

name: Antenna Subequal To Head
description: Antennae about as long head

name: Antennal Segment Articulation
description: 2nd antennal segment attached at apex of 1st (basal-most) segment

name: Clubbed Antennae
description: Antennal segments 7–9 clubbed.

name: Long Maxillary Palpi
description: Maxillary palpi usually longer than antennae.

name: Base of Mandibles with Bristles
description: Pair of brushes of bristles above bases of mandibles.

name: Mandibles Moving Vertically
description: Mandibles moving vertically and parallel to one another.

name: Pair of Long Tubercles Fringed with Hair
description: Last abdominal segment with pair of long tubercles fringed with hair.

name: Prolegs Present Ventrally from segments 1-8
description: A pair of prolegs present on abdominal segments 1-8

name: Slender Tubercles on 2-7
description: Abdominal segments 2–7 each with two pairs of slender tubercles laterally and dorsally, 1 pair of spiny prolegs ventrally.

name: Head Capsule Complete but Not Distinct
description: Head capsule complete but not distinctly separated from thorax.

name: Mandibles Moving Horizontally
description: Mandibles moving horizontally against each other.

name: Suction Cup on Each Body Division
description: Body divided into 6 major divisions, each with single suction cup ventrally.

name: Head Complete and Exposed
description: Head complete and fully exposed. The head is not drawn into the thorax.

name: With Or Without Prolegs
description: Prolegs (fleshy nubs) can be present or absent on the prothorax (1st thoracic segment). Like in the specimen imaged here (Probezzia), if prolegs are absent the body is usually smooth, shiny, and cream colored, usually without any surface features except a few hairs especially posteriorly, and sometimes a single retractile anal proleg bearing a few hooks. Alternatively, if there is a pair of ventral prolegs on the prothorax, then the prothoracic and anal prolegs are usually paired (even if divison slight and only at apex) and there are distinct dorsal fleshy projections and/or setae along body.

name: Head Complete and Exposed
description: Head complete and fully exposed. The head is not drawn into the thorax.

name: Thoracic And Anal Prolegs
description: Paired hook-bearing prolegs (fleshy nubs used for movement) are present on the prothorax and at the posterior end of the body. At first glance these may appear as a single proleg, but they are paired, the division may be slight and only at the apex of the proleg.

name: Fused Thoracic Segments
description: Thoracic segments fused, nearly indistinguishable, wider than head and abdomen.

name: Head Capsule Complete and Exposed
description: Head capsule complete, fully exposed.

name: Mandibles Moving Horizontally
description: Mandibles moving horizontally against each other.

name: Slender Antennae with Short Setae
description: Antennae slender with short setae.

name: Distinct Thoracic Segments
description: Thoracic segments clearly evident, no wider than abdomen.

name: Flat Lobes Fringed with Hair on Last Segment
description: Last abdominal segment with pair of flat lobes fringed with hair.

name: Head Capsule Complete and Exposed
description: Head capsule complete, fully exposed.

name: Hook-bearing Prolegs on 1-2
description: First and (usually) second abdominal segments each with pair of hook-bearing prolegs.

name: Mandibles Moving Horizontally
description: Mandibles moving horizontally against each other.

name: 1-4 Rounded Lobes on End of Abdomen
description: End of abdomen with 1–4 rounded lobes with apical setae.

name: All Abdominal Segments with Hook-bearing Prolegs
description: Abdominal segments each bearing pair of prolegs with apical hooks.

name: Head Capsule Not Sclerotized and Exposed
description: Head capsule exposed, mostly not sclerotized, reduced to slender rods that are prominent internally.

name: Mouth Hooks Moving Vertically
description: Mouth hooks moving vertically and parallel with each other.

name: Spiracles Absent
description: Spiracles usually absent.

name: All Abdominal Segments with Hook-bearing Prolegs
description: Abdominal segments each bearing pair of prolegs with apical hooks.

name: Head Retracted in Thorax
description: The hardened head capsule is not visible from the outside, it is always deeply retracted inside thorax, and can only be viewed with dissection.

name: Head Retracted in Thorax
description: The hardened head capsule is not visible from the outside, it is always deeply retracted inside thorax, and can only be viewed with dissection.

name: Posterior Spiracles with Lobes
description: The posterior spiracles are rimmed by 2–7 (usually 5) lobes often fringed with hair.

name: Head Not Externally Sclerotized
description: Head capsule not sclerotized externally.

name: Last Segment Blunt, Smooth
description: Last abdominal segment blunt, smooth.

name: Mouth Hooks Moving Vertically
description: Mouth hooks moving vertically and parallel with each other.

name: Posterior Spiracles each with 3 Slits
description: Pair of posterior spiracles each with 3 sinuous slits.

name: Head Capsule Sclerotized and Mostly Retracted
description: Head capsule sclerotized and mostly retracted in membranous body.

name: Long Ventral Lobes on Abdominal Apex
description: End of abdomen with pair of spiracles and pair of long ventral lobes.

name: Mandibles Moving Horizontally
description: Mandibles moving horizontally against each other.

name: Body Segments Subdivided
description: All body segments secondarily divided into 2–3 subdivisions most of which bear dorsal sclerotized plates.

name: Distinct Thoracic Segments
description: Thoracic segments clearly evident, no wider than abdomen.

name: Head Capsule Complete and Exposed
description: Head capsule complete, fully exposed.

name: Mandibles Moving Horizontally
description: Mandibles moving horizontally against each other.

name: Head Capsule Complete and Exposed
description: Head capsule complete, fully exposed.

name: Hooked Prolegs on 1-3
description: First 3 abdominal segments each with ventral pair of prolegs, each with single apical hook.

name: Long Respiratory Siphon
description: End of abdomen with long retractile respiratory siphon.

name: Mandibles Moving Horizontally
description: Mandibles moving horizontally against each other.

name: Abdomen Swollen Posteriorly
description: Abdominal segments 5–8 are swollen, appearing ballooned or bowling-pin-like. Often these balooned posterior ends are attached to the substrate.

name: Head Complete and Exposed
description: Head complete and fully exposed. The head is not drawn into the thorax.

name: Labral Fans
description: Head capsule usually with pair of conspicuous fans.

name: Body Flattened
description: Body somewhat depressed.

name: Head Capsule Sclerotized and Mostly Exposed
description: Head capsule sclerotized and mostly exposed, incapable of independent movement.

name: Leathery Integument
description: Integument tough, leathery, with calcium deposits evident as small facets.

name: Mandibles Moving Vertically
description: Mandibles moving vertically and parallel to one another.

name: Head Not Externally Sclerotized
description: Head capsule not sclerotized externally.

name: Mouth Hooks Moving Vertically
description: Mouth hooks moving vertically and parallel with each other.

name: Posterior Spiracles Fused
description: Posterior spiracles fused or abutting, usually on apex of retractile respiratory tube.

name: Head Capsule Sclerotized and Mostly Retracted
description: Head capsule sclerotized and mostly retracted in membranous body, usually with longitudinal incisions posteriorly or reduced to long rods.

name: Lobed Posterior Spiracles with Hair
description: Posterior pair of spiracles bordered by at least 6 lobes fringed with hair.

name: Mandibles Moving Horizontally
description: Mandibles moving horizontally against each other.

name: Notched Upper Lip
description: The labrum (upper lip) usually has a median notch. The labrum or upper-lip is a flap-like structure covering the mouthparts. You are looking for an indentation or dip along the far edge.

name: Pectinate Spines On Maxillae
description: Maxillae (second pair of jaws) each with row of conspicuous pectinate (comb-like) spines.

name: Short Antennae
description: Antennae short, less than twice width of head.  Refer to Baetidae for longer than head antenna.

name: Long Antenna
description: The antennae are usually long, two or three times or more width of the head

name: Notched Upper Lip
description: The labrum (upper lip) usually has a median notch. The labrum or upper-lip is a flap-like structure covering the mouthparts. You are looking for an indentation or dip along the far edge.

name: Shield-like Pronotum
description: Pronotum forming large shield over rest of thorax and 5 basal segments of abdomen.

name: Square Semioperculate Gills
description: Paired gills on abdominal segment 2 are nearly square, and meeting or almost meeting medially (but NOT fused). These gills on segment 2 are at least partially covering the succeeding pairs (semioperculate).

name: Segment 2 Without Gills
description: This is the only mayfly family with gills absent on abdominal segment 2.

name: Fluffy Abdominal Gills
description: Abdominal gills on segments 2–7 are conspicuous dorsaly, forked and elongate-lancolate, with fringed margins, giving the animal a fluffy appearance.

name: Fossorial Foretibiae
description: The Foretibiae (the shins of the first pair of legs), are expanded/enlarged, and used for burrowing in sediment.

name: Large Tusks
description: Large Tusks for are located anterioly on the head.

name: Pointed Hind Tibiae
description: Ventral apex of each hind tibia acutely pointed (i.e. the shins of the last pair of legs each have a point at the end).

name: Flat Head And Body
description: Head and body dorsoventrally flattened (flattend from top to bottom).

name: Margin Around Eyes
description: Lateral margins of head visible beside the eyes.

name: Operculate Gill On 2
description: The gills on abdominal segment 2 are operculate or semioperculate. (i.e. the gills on this segment at least partially cover the gills on the preceeding segment). The gills are and roughly triangular or oval.

name: Double Lamellate Gills
description: The gills on abdominal segments 2–7 are double-layered and lamellate (plate-like). The gills can be terminated in filaments or points and without fringe, or oval with fringe.

name: Foreleg Claws Bifid
description: Claw on each foreleg bifid.

name: Gills on 1-7 Plate-like
description: Pair of plate-like gills present on abdominal segments 1–7.

name: Gills on 2-7 Forked, Long, Curving over Abdomen
description: Gills on abdominal segments 2–7 forked, long, tapered, fringed with hair, curving over top of abdomen.

name: Legs Flattened or Tuberculate
description: Legs flattened or tuberculate.

name: Long Tusks Straight or Downcurved
description: Mandibles each with long tusk straight or downcurved.

name: ​Hind Tibiae Rounded Apically
description: Hind tibiae rounded apically.

name: Gills on 2-7 Forked, Long, Projecting Laterad
description: Gills on abdominal segments 2–7 forked, long, tapered, fringed with hair, projecting laterad.

name: Legs Slender
description: Legs slender.

name: Long Tusks
description: Mandibles each with long tusk.

name: 3 "Tails" Subequal
description: Median caudal filament as long as cerci.

name: Distal Margin of Labrum Straight
description: Distal margin of labrum straight, not notched.

name: Gills on 1-7 Plate-like
description: Pair of plate-like gills present on abdominal segments 1–7.

name: Short Antennae
description: Antennae short, less than twice width of head.  Refer to Baetidae for longer than head antenna.

name: Antennae Shorter than Head
description: Antennae shorter than head, not visible from above.

name: Flat Air Straps on Abdominal Apex
description: Apex of abdomen with pair of short, flat, retractile air straps.

name: Antennae Shorter than Head
description: Antennae shorter than head, not visible from above.

name: Scoop-like Front Tarsi
description: Each front tarsus a single segment, scoop-like, fringed with stiff setae.

name: Short, Triangular Beak
description: Beak triangular, very short, unsegmented.

name: Anteapical Claws
description: At least front tarsus (last leg segment) with anteapical claws. These are claws that protrude from leg before the apex.

name: Antennae Longer than Head
description: Antennae longer than head, visible from above.

name: Hind Femora Longer than Abdomen
description: Hind femora much longer than abdomen.

name: Middle Legs Closer to Hind Legs
description: Middle legs arising closer to hind legs than to front legs.

name: Eyes Contiguous With Head
description: Similar in appearence to Belostomatidae (giant water bugs) except that margins of eyes are contiguous with anterior margin of head in Naucoridae; i.e. the eyes are right against the edge of the head.

name: Raptorial Legs
description: Forelegs are raptorial, suitable for use in predation, with broad femora, and weakly convex dorsally.

name: Antennae Shorter than Head
description: Antennae shorter than head, not visible from above.

name: Long Breathing Tube on Abdominal Apex
description: Apex of abdomen with long cylindrical breathing tube that is not retractile.

name: Antennae Shorter than Head
description: Antennae shorter than head, not visible from above.

name: Body Convex Dorsally
description: Body strongly convex dorsally.

name: Long, Oar-like Hind Legs
description: Hind legs longer than others, oar-like, its claws inconspicuous.

name: Swimming Hairs on Legs
description: Middle and hind legs with fringes of swimming hairs.

name: Anteapical Claws
description: At least front tarsus (last leg segment) with anteapical claws. These are claws that protrude from leg before the apex.

name: Antennae Longer Than Head
description: The antennae are longer than the head. They are positioned anterior to the eyes, clearly visible from the dorsal side.

name: Hind Femora Short
description: The hind femora are shorter than the abdomen, or just barely longer.

name: 2 Setae in Front of Each Lateral Spiracle
description: Prothorax with 2 setae in front of each lateral spiracle.

name: Prolegs on 3-6 with Crochets
description: Prolegs of abdominal sterna 3–6 with crochets (tiny hooks) arranged in an ellipse, or two transverse lines.

name: 5 Short Appendages on End of Abdomen
description: End of abdomen with 5 short, stiff, pointed appendages.

name: No Dorsal Premental Setae
description: Labial prementum without dorsal setae.

name: No Palpal Setae
description: Labial palps parallel-sided and usually without setae.

name: Prementum and Palps Flat
description: Labial prementum and palps flat beneath head.

name: Slender, Bristle-like Antennae
description: Antennae slender, bristle-like.

name: 1st Antennal Segment Long
description: First antennal segment (segment nearest the head) long, subequal to length of rest of antenna.

name: 3 Tracheal Gills
description: End of abdomen with 3 long, tracheal gills.

name: 3 Tracheal Gills
description: End of abdomen with 3 long, tracheal gills.

name: Antennal Segment 1 Short
description: Antennal segment 1 much shorter than the rest of the antenna.

name: Mask without Cleft
description: Ligula (distal part of palm of mask) usually without median cleft. The mask is roughly triangular or square (not stalked as in Lestidae).

name: 5 Short Appendages on End of Abdomen
description: End of abdomen with 5 short, stiff, pointed appendages.

name: Dorsal Premental Setae
description: Dorsal premental setae present. These are hairs located inside the mask, on the palm. If the mask is closed you will have to use forceps to gently open it.

name: Margins of Labial Palps Toothed
description: Labial palps with distal margins deeply incised into large, irregular teeth.

name: Palpal Setae
description: Palpal Setae are present. These are hair along the margins of the palpal lobes (at end of mask).

name: Prementum and Palps Spoon-like
description: Labial prementum and palps spoon-like.

name: 5 Short Appendages on End of Abdomen
description: End of abdomen with 5 short, stiff, pointed appendages.

name: Dorsal Premental Setae
description: Dorsal premental setae present. These are hairs located inside the mask, on the palm. If the mask is closed you will have to use forceps to gently open it.

name: Median Groove
description: Ventrally, there is a median groove extending from the basal hinge of the mask to about 1/3 to 1/2 way to the distal margin of mask. It is often faint.

name: Palpal Setae
description: Palpal Setae are present. These are hair along the margins of the palpal lobes (at end of mask).

name: Spoon-shaped Mask
description: Labial mask spoon-shaped. This is a arm-like extremity that covers the mouth parts and is used for capturing prey.

name: 4-Segmented Antennae
description: The antennae are each 4-segmented, although the 4th segment is often small.

name: Flat Mask
description: Labial mask flattened. This is a arm-like extremity that covers the mouth parts and is used for capturing prey.

name: 3 Tracheal Gills
description: End of abdomen with 3 long, tracheal gills.

name: Base of Prementum Long and Slender
description: Base of labial prementum long, slender.

name: 5 Short Appendages on End of Abdomen
description: End of abdomen with 5 short, stiff, pointed appendages.

name: Median Groove Absent
description: Unlike in Corduliidae, the prementum (basal hinge of the mask) is usually without a ventral basal medial groove.

name: Spoon-shaped Mask
description: Labial mask spoon-shaped. This is a arm-like extremity that covers the mouth parts and is used for capturing prey.

name: Gills Absent
description: Filamentous gills absent from thoracic and abdominal segments.

name: Hind Legs Don't Reach
description: When extended, hind legs do not reach end of the abdomen.

name: Membranous Pleural Fold
description: This is found on the side of the abdomen.  In Leuctridae, it is no more than 1-7 segments long and in Capniidae, the fold is 1-9 segments long.

name: Paraglossae And Glossae Subequal
description: Paraglossae and glossae about same length, suitable for shredding.

name: Small Postmentum
description: Postmentum small, not covering bases of maxillae.

name: Gills Absent
description: Filamentous gills absent from thoracic and abdominal segments.

name: Glossae Shorter Than Paraglossae
description: Glossae much shorter than the paraglossae.

name: Hind Legs Reach
description: When extended, hind legs reach about to the end of the abdomen.

name: Short Cerci
description: Cerci no more than 3/4 as long as abdomen.

name: Thoracic Terga Plain
description: Thoracic terga (segments) without a dark pattern, setting this family apart from the often more patterned stonefly nymphs in the families Perlidae and Perlodidae.

name: Hind Legs Don't Reach
description: When extended, hind legs do not reach end of the abdomen.

name: Large Postmentum
description: Postmentum large, covering bases of maxillae

name: Membranous Pleural Fold
description: This is found on the side of the abdomen.  In Leuctridae, it is no more than 1-7 segments long and in Capniidae, the fold is 1-9 segments long.

name: Parallel Hind Wing Pads
description: Hind wing pads more or less parallel with body axis, and typically longer than wide.

name: Divergent Hind Wing Pads
description: Hind wing pads (2nd pair of wing pads) conspicuously divergent from body axis

name: Hind Legs Reach
description: When extended, hind legs reach about to the end of the abdomen.

name: Paraglossae And Glossae Subequal
description: Paraglossae and glossae about same length, suitable for shredding.

name: Conical Thoracic Gills
description: Thoracic gills conical in shape and occur singly or doubly.

name: Paraglossae And Glossae Subequal
description: Paraglossae and glossae about same length, suitable for shredding.

name: Roach-like Body
description: Mayfly nymphs of this family have a broad, roach-like body.

name: Thoracic Sterna Overlapping
description: Thoracic sterna produced posteriorly, each overlapping succeeding segment.

name: Gills Absent
description: Filamentous gills absent from thoracic and abdominal segments.

name: Glossae Shorter Than Paraglossae
description: Glossae much shorter than the paraglossae.

name: Tails Subequal To Abdomen
description: Cerci (tails) are about the same length as the abdomen.

name: Gill Tufts on Thorax and Abdomen
description: Tufts of filamentous gills on thorax and first two abdominal segments.

name: Paraglossae And Glossae Subequal
description: Paraglossae and glossae about same length, suitable for shredding.

name: Mesonotum sclerotized
description: The mesonotum of larvae in this family is covered with a pair of sclerites.

name: Metanotum mostly membranous
description: The metanotum of larvae in this family usually has 2–3 pairs of small sclerites, but is mostly membranous.

name: Setose metanotum
description: More than 25 setae are distributed transversely in the anteromesal region of the metanotum.

name: Smooth mandibular margins
description: Mandibles with inner margins usually smooth, without teeth.

name: ​Antenna Midway Between Eye and Mandible
description: Larvae have tiny antennae each midway between an eye and its corresponding mandible.

name: ​Hooded sand case
description: Portable sand case of sand and papoose-like, extended over larval head.

name: Mesonotum sclerotized
description: The mesonotum of larvae in this family is covered with a pair of sclerites.

name: Metanotum mostly membranous
description: The metanotum of larvae in this family usually has 2 pairs of small sclerites posteromesally and laterally, but is mostly membranous.

name: ​Humpless abdominal segment I
description: First abdominal segment lacking membranous lateral humps (can be expanded or collapsed).

name: ​Transversely arranged plant-material case
description: Portable case of slender plant materials arranged transversely.  The plant materials can be either wrapped around the insect to form a tapered cylinder, or they can be organized to make a four-sided log-cabin tube.

name: Mesonotum sclerotized
description: The mesonotum of larvae in this family is covered with a pair of sclerites.

name: ​Dead leaf or hollowed-twig case
description: The larvae of this family create a portable case either made with two dead leaves on top of one another, or out of a hollowed stick or other piece of wood.

name: ​Metanotum mostly membranous
description: The metanotum has 1 pair of small lateral sclerites, but is mostly membranous.

name: ​Setae on labrum
description: The labrum of this family has a transverse row of 16 setae across the middle, giving these caddisflies a mustached appearance.

name: Branching Retreat
description: Larvae make branching tube-like retreats buried in sand or soft sediment, except tips of branches sticking above sediment. You can find these by using a seave in soft sandy sediment, look for branching sandy tubes, often with a bulbus end on one of the branches, carfully pull it apart to find the larva.

name: Hump Between Nota
description: The Meso- and metanota (2nd and 3rd dorsal thorasic segments) are membranous (not hardened) with a large hump between them.

name: Large Spinneret
description: Large spinneret, half as long as head. This is a needle-like structure near the mouth, where the silk is extruded.

name: Tarsi Flattened
description: Tarsi (toes- distal most leg region) flattened and tibiae (shins) shorter than tarsi

name: Membranous mesonotum
description: The mesonotum is entirely or mostly membranous in larvae of this family.

name: Membranous metanotum
description: The metanotum is entirely or mostly membranous in larvae of this family.

name: Metanotum with 3 pairs of setae
description: Larvae in this family have 3 pairs of setae (hairs) on their metanotum.

name: ​Abdominal Segment IX with Small Sclerite
description: The top of the last abdominal segment (segment IX) has one small sclerite.

name: ​Dome-like case
description: Portable case of small rocks, dome-like, with transverse ventral strap of fine sand.

name: ​Mesonotum with 3 pairs of setae
description: Larvae in this family have 3 pairs of setae (hairs) on their mesonotum.

name: Mesonotum sclerotized
description: The mesonotum of larvae from this family is covered with 2 pairs of sclerites and has an additional pair of thick lateral sclerites projecting anterad (toward the head of the caddisfly) beside the pronotum.

name: Metanotum Mostly Membranous
description: The metanotum has 1 pair of small lateral sclerites, but is mostly membranous.

name: ​Antenna Midway Between Eye and Mandible
description: Larvae have tiny antennae each midway between an eye and its corresponding mandible.

name: ​Tubular Case with Large Ballast Stones
description: Tubular portable case made of stones with two pairs of larger, nearly symmetrical lateral “ballast” stones.

name: Snail shell-like case
description: The portable case of sand grains Helicopsychid larvae construct resembles a snail shell.

name: Mesonotum sclerotized
description: The mesonotum of larvae in this family is covered with a pair of sclerites.

name: Pronotum Sclerotized
description: A pair of sclerites completely covers the pronotum of larvae in this family.

name: Short Overall Length
description: Caddisflies of this family are very small - the larvae are less than ½ inch (6 mm) long.

name: ​Flattened Case
description: Larvae of this family construct a portable or stationary case of plant or mineral material and it is usually either compressed (flattened from sides) or depressed (flattened from top and bottom), giving it a purse-like appearance, rarely tubular.

name: ​Metanotum Sclerotized
description: A pair of sclerites completely covers the metanotum of larvae in this family.

name: ​No Ventral Abdominal Gills
description: Larvae of this family lack gills on the underside of their abdomens.

name: ​Tiny Anal Claws
description: Anal prolegs usually not projecting and anal claws tiny.

name: Antenna Next To Eye
description: The antenna are small and are always situated directly next to the eye. This is the only caddisfly family with antenna in this location.

name: "Long" Antenna
description: This is the only caddisfly family where the larvae usually have “long” antenna. By long antenna we mean that they aren’t tiny little nubs we usually see on caddisflies, but more like short threads, easily visible in profile.

name: Mesonotum sclerotized
description: The mesonotum of larvae in this family is covered with a pair of sclerites.

name: Tubular, Flanged Sand Case
description: Larvae of this family make a portable case of sand that is tubular but appears very flat with wide lateral flanges and anterodorsal cowel over larval head.

name: ​Metanotum Mostly Membranous
description: The metanotum has 0-1 pairs of small lateral sclerites, but is mostly membranous.

name: ​Small Hind Leg Claws
description: Claws of hind legs much smaller than those of front and middle legs.

name: Mesonotum sclerotized
description: The mesonotum of larvae in this family is covered with a pair of sclerites.

name: Sturdy Sand Case
description: Larvae of this family make a sturdy portable case of coarse sand cemented with mortar-like bands of silk.

name: ​Metanotum Usually with 4 Sclerites
description: Larvae of Odontoceridae usually have one broad transverse anterior sclerite, one narrow transverse posterior sclerite, and one pair of lateral sclerites on the metanotum.  Rarely, the metanotum will have 3 pairs of small sclerites.

name: ​Pronotum with Pointed Anterolateral Corners
description: The pronotum of larvae in this family usually has strongly pointed anterolateral corners, giving larvae the appearance of having sharp shoulder pads.

name: T-Shaped Labrum
description: Labrum (upper lip) membranous and T-shaped. If you don't see the labrum it's becuase in preserved specimens it’s often sucked into mouth and hidden from view. All other families have a sclerotized easily visible labrum.

name: Membranous mesonotum
description: The mesonotum is entirely or mostly membranous in larvae of this family.

name: Membranous metanotum
description: The metanotum is entirely or mostly membranous in larvae of this family.

name: Setose Lateral Sclerites on Meso- and Metanota
description: Larvae in this family have on their mesonotum and metanotum a pair of lateral sclerites with many setae.

name: ​Abdominal Segment IX with Small Sclerite
description: The top of the last abdominal segment (segment IX) has one small sclerite.

name: ​Mesonotum with 2 Pairs of Setae
description: Caddisfly larvae in this family have on their mesonotum 2 pairs of dorsomesal setae (hairs).

name: ​Metanotum with 2 Pairs of Setae
description: Larvae in this family have on their metanotum 2 pairs of dorsomesal setae (hairs).

name: ​Spiraling or Ringed Plant Case
description: Larvae of this family make a portable case of plant materials arranged in a spiral or in successive rings.

name: ​Stiff Prosternal Horn
description: Stiff prosternal horn present between front legs.

name: Abdominal Segment IX Membranous
description: Top of last abdominal segment (segment IX) membranous.

name: Membranous Mesonotum
description: The mesonotum is membranous in larvae of this family.

name: Membranous Metanotum
description: The metanotum is membranous in larvae of this family.

name: Mesonotum with 3 Pairs of Setae
description: Larvae in this family have 3 pairs of setae (hairs) on their mesonotum, with the posteromesal and/or lateral pair sometimes doubled.

name: Metanotum with 3 Pairs of Setae
description: Larvae in this family have 3 pairs of setae (hairs) on their mesonotum, with the posteromesal and/or lateral pair sometimes doubled.

name: ​Long, Free Anal Prolegs
description: The anal prolegs of this family are long and freely movable.

name: Hatchet-shaped Foretrochantin
description: The foretrochantin is a projecting sclerite (hard plate) at the base of each foreleg. This is the only family where the foretrochantin is hatched-shaped. Look from the ventral side, you may see the shape more clearly if the specimen is a bit tilted.

name: Anal Prolegs Free
description: Anal prolegs (fleshy nubs at the end of th body with hooks on them) are free, not closely fused to the abdomen.

name: Free-living
description: Larvae are free-living (do not build a case or retreat) until pupation.

name: Meso- And Metanota Membranous.
description: Meso- and metanota membranous. I.e. Dorsally, only the first thorasic segment is sclerotized (hardened), the rest of the thorax is membranous.

name: Sclerite On Segment IX
description: The dorsal side of abdominal segment 9 has a sclerite (hardened plate or patch). Segment 9 is the last abdominal segment, at the end of the body.

name: Curved, Smooth Sand Case
description: Larvae of this family create a portable case that is smooth, slightly curved, and made of fine sand.

name: Mesonotum sclerotized
description: The mesonotum of larvae in this family is covered with a pair of sclerites.

name: Metanotum Mostly Membranous
description: Metanotum with 3 pairs of small sclerites, but mostly membranous.

name: ​Pronotum with Pointed Anterolateral Corners
description: The pronotum of larvae in this family usually has strongly pointed anterolateral corners, giving larvae the appearance of having sharp shoulder pads.

name: ​Setose Anal Prolegs
description: Each anal proleg has a mesodorsal cluster of at least 30 setae.

name: Notched Mesonotum
description: Mesonotum notched medially along the anterior margin. I.e. the middle thoracic segment has 2 small incisions along the edge nearest the head.

name: Only Metanotum Membranous
description: Pro- and mesonota are sclerotized, but the metanotum mostly membranous, with some small sclerites (i.e. the dorsal sides of the 1st two thoracic segments are hardened, but the 3rd is membranous).

name: 5-Segmented Swimming Legs
description: Long, slender swimming legs 5-segmented, excluding 2 claws.

name: 8-Segmented Abdomen
description: Abdomen with 8 segments.

name: Sickle-Shaped Mandibles
description: Sickle-shaped mandibles without mola (grinding surface).

name: Brown, Sclerotized, Spindle-Shaped Body
description: Body strongly sclerotized (hardened), dark brown or red-brown, roughly cylindrical or spindle-shaped,

name: Operculum
description: Segment 9 (posterior-most segment) with ventral lid-like flap (operculum) concealing thread-like gills and pair of hooks

name: 4 Posterior Hooks
description: Abdominal segment 10 (posterior-most segment) with 4 stout hooks.

name: 5-Segmented Legs + Claws
description: Legs 5-segmented plus 2 tarsal claws.

name: Lateral Gills
description: Abdominal segments 1–9 with lateral gills.

name: 5-Segmented Legs + Claw
description: Legs 5-segmented and each with single claw.

name: Dorsal Projections
description: Mature larvae usually with long, slender, stiff, needle-like dorsal projections from thoracic and abdominal segments

name: Flat Body
description: The body is dorsoventrally flattened (flat like a hamburger, not like a taco).

name: Shield-Like
description: The thoracic and abdominal tergites (dorsal hardened segmental plates) are expanded laterally as a thin shield covering the head and legs from above. This can make the animals resemble trilobites. This shape also helps them stick to rocks almost like a suction cup.

name: 3 or Less Antennal Segments
description: Antennae with 3 or fewer segments.

name: 4-Segmented Legs
description: Legs each with 4 segments.

name: 9-Segmented Abdomen
description: Abdomen with 9 segments.

name: Distinct Labrum
description: Distinct labrum present.

name: Operculum lacking
description: Lacking operculum on last segment.

name: Posterior Gill Tufts
description: Anal region with tufts of gills.
